Emergency Conservation Regulation
With California still experiencing severe drought despite recent rains, on February 2, 2016 the State Water Board adopted an extended and revised emergency regulation to ensure that urban water conservation continues in 2016. The regulation extends restrictions on urban water use through October 2016 while providing urban water suppliers more flexibility in meeting their conservation requirements. It also directs staff to report back on additional flexibility once more complete water supply information is known in April.

Pros: El Nino rainfalls will likely not be enough to sustainably fill CA reservoirs. In TX in 2015 the drought was ended when the reservoirs filled but the magnitude of the problem in CA is much greater; it would take almost double the yearly average rainfall in order to bring the conditions out of the bottom 20% of 4-year average accumulations. Further, many reservoirs in CA are filled via imports that come from snow melt in the mountains, which is expected to decrease this year. Also, El Nino is notoriously unpredictable, creating even greater uncertainty as to its effects (likelihood of not filling reservoirs: 95%). Further, the question states that even modifications to the rules count as an extension, this includes loosening (but not eliminating) restrictions. Given the info above regarding El Nino rainfalls, if the CA government decides to change usage rules, a loosening is much more likely than a total elimination (85%). 
Cons: El Nino is particularly strong this year and so far is concentrated in the upper part of California, where most of the state's reservoirs exist. Also, given El Nino's unpredictable nature, it is possible (5%) that we see an extraordinarily convenient weather pattern. Also, the question specifically states urban water use as opposed to agriculture water use. Urban use only accounts for about 20% of the state's water usage. This creates political uncertainty as the Democrat urban areas may feel unfairly burdened by the restrictions compared to the more Republican rural areas. However, there is little evidence of these political pressures at work (10%).
